sections.content: Drawing is one of the most universal forms of artistic expression. Artists use simple elements like line, shape, and texture to create images that communicate ideas, emotions, and stories. In this lesson, we will explore these three fundamental components of drawing and learn how they can be used creatively to make art. Mastering these basics opens the door to endless artistic possibilities.
sections.title: Introduction to Drawing Techniques

sections.content:
A line is the most basic element of drawing. It can be straight, curved, thick, thin, or broken. Lines define shapes, create movement, and express emotion. Types of lines include:
- **Contour lines**: Define the edges of objects.
- **Crosshatching**: Overlapping lines used to create shading and texture.
- **Gesture lines**: Quick, fluid lines capturing motion or form.
For example, when drawing a tree, the trunk could be a straight line, while curved lines form irregular branches, and crosshatching adds bark texture.
sections.title: The Power of the Line

sections.content:
Shapes are created when lines connect to form enclosed spaces. They can be geometric (e.g., squares, triangles) or organic (e.g., irregular, freeform shapes). Artists use shapes to structure their artwork. For example:
- A house might use a square for the base, a triangle for the roof, and rectangles for windows and doors.
Overlapping shapes can create depth, such as layering circles and ovals to form flower petals.
sections.title: Shapes in Art

sections.content:
Texture refers to the surface quality of an object—how it feels or looks like it would feel. In drawing, texture can be visual (implied through patterns) or physical (created by the medium). Techniques include:
- **Stippling**: Using dots to suggest roughness or softness.
- **Scratching**: Mimicking textures like wood grain or fur.
For example, to draw a brick wall, straight lines and stippling can create the roughness of the bricks. Experimenting with textures enhances the dynamism of your artwork.
sections.title: Texture Brings Drawings to Life
